displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: But that’s something may not be so as aggressive or as detrimental on your quality of life as the hormone therapy, for example, which has all these systemic side effects. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So I wasn’t necessarily seeing it as hormones plus radiation at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I was seeing it as doing the radiation therapy as a way to sort of avoid or push back the need for the hormones. Family Member: Because the radiation is just going to target that one area. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Correct. Family Member: And the cancer still. Healthcare Professional: But the thing is, too, you’ll also be observed. You know so you’ll still be getting PSA levels done. I don’t know when he will repeat scans but you’ll get another set of scans. So it’s not; it’s not like you wouldn’t still have information along the way to like initiate the hormones if it comes after the you know – Patient: Okay.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Standard stuff. Trials. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So standard stuff, you’ve now had kind of the standard hormone treatments. Both of the two that we have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Zytiga and Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You have Provenge. Um, so um, the one standard thing that’s left is a radiation-based thing but that’s really only for disease of the bone. You have lymph node as well. So I would sort of not use that. The other thing that’s left is chemotherapy, flavors, uh so that’s something we could always go to. The other sort of unfortunately gray zone (beeping) Patient: Sure. Doctor: Uh and some of that’s clinical trial. A lot of the clinical trials we have right now are hormonal based. So it’s Zytiga plus something, Xtandi plus something. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Versus something. So unfortunately uh you wouldn’t fit all those trials because of the prior treatments we have.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, and then, huh, they’ll usually reach out to you about that results. And then, huh, huh, and then I have an appointment if you check out that will coincide with your next shot. Patient: Right. Doctor: Blood work a few days in advance at B___ and a visit with me. So likely that you’re going to be on the abiraterone as you come into that visit. Huh, it’s just an issue of us getting it started. So if you haven’t heard in the next ten days let me know. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, because of the Medicare switch, that may be sort of the only delay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: All righty. Doctor: Good? Family Member: That’s fine. Doctor: Okay?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no? Doctor: We'll we'll check the protocol to make sure there's no future drug interaction, but I think it's fine Family Member 2: Okay, do you want a prescription referral? Do you need a prescription? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Is that okay? I don't have any left. Doctor: We always prefer Restiril, have you ever been? So that's actually probably a better sleeper. Family Member 2: Restiril. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: It’s pretty strong. Doctor: I like that better and less addictive than Ambien. Family Member 1: Oh, okay. Okay, questions. My one daughter is pregnant. Then we watch her her little two year old. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: About three times a week.

Patient: And my PSA wasn’t on the sheet. Do you guys have a number on that? Doctor: It’s not back. Did you do it yesterday? No today. Patient: We did labs today. Doctor: Oh, okay. No it’s not back yet then. I’ll take a look and let you know but Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it’s back. Family Member: Next Friday we’ll be back to plan out the next step and… Doctor: That’s what I’m thinking. Family Member: The tests should be back by then? Doctor: Yeah, but you know what just for now wait for a phone call and I’ll have S call you as soon as we get the results so we can sort of plan better for that Friday. Family Member: So it’s just a one day in and out thing? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Show me how is the shoulder doing? Patient: Oh the shoulders are good.

Patient: No. Family Member: So what about, okay you said radiation on the prostate. Doctor: I didn’t say that. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I’m saying that may be an option. Family Member: May be an option. Doctor: Because where we’ve been you know we’ve been talking about you know hormones is the base layer and then do we add chemotherapy on top of that? And then we talked to you about the clinical trial – Patient: Right. Doctor: - which is you know potentially adding a third drug on top of it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So three punches versus two punches. Patient: Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the good news is there are a number of different treatments. Uh, you know, this one is worth a try, but otherwise there are hormonal pills or other really effective things, too, that we can use outside of the study. Okay? Family Member: So, we don’t have to go through the study? Doctor: So what we’re going to ask is we will make a request, as long as you’re okay with it, to see if the study is accepting new people and if, you know, we’ll send you a case description in. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: As long as but I need your okay for that. Patient: Okay. Family Member: That’s fine. Doctor: And if I have that, uh, if they say that, yes, we can go ahead, we’ll let you know and we’ll have them come back to do all the consenting and all of that procedure. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If, however, they say, not right now, it’s too much, if it’s a week or two, I’m okay with waiting. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s going to be a month or more, I don’t think then we should wait. We should look into other things.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: For this, I’ve got a, I think for this, the trial, they were able to use the experience with Germany to say you probably could start about here. You don’t have to start way down here. And I don’t think it’s the same exactly like a regular drug phase one. So I think they’re kind of already in a in a sort of Goldilocks spot. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So that’s the only difference between you know in Germany everybody gets, they individualize it based on what they looked at is how much of the scan is your cancer taking off. They try, they, they describe what they said that if you took up that much material, you need to get this much. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So they give, they dose it based on how much of an exposure. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, I think, again, what’s the best way to go? I mean the groups in Germany have way more experience doing this. Family Member: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh but you know it’s more complicated because you’ve got to go to Germany and all that, all those, there’s, there’s a layer to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Although you know saying that, you still would have to go away from home.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think he’s mentioned in his note a standard option for you go to would be to chemotherapy. So chemotherapy in someone like you after hormones haven’t worked well enough or long enough; Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: chemotherapy shrinks the PSA for a while, shrinks the tumor for a while in about forty/fifty percent of people. So almost half the people get some benefit from chemotherapy. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We usually know after three or four cycles as to whether or not it’s gonna help, and we keep going. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We also sort of know what side effects you’re going to experience to sort of see whether you can tolerate this. We have to adjust the doses about that. So that’s an approved drug that’s known to extend survival if people get the drugs, tolerate the drugs, respond to the drugs. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know those people can do well compared to those who don’t respond or don’t get the drug. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So chemo would be something that you know it could be given here, it could be given there, but it’s standard treatment.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But we, the is if you drop out Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but every once in a while we make an exception , but in general the cavet is dropping out early is you Patient: And this therapy is part of the trial, it’s not just something that’s being done, it’s associated with this trial. It’s not and say this is what I want to do at this time. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: This only comes with this trial. Doctor: That is generally true. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Um now the last time, there are some radiologist oncologists that insurance is Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And again, Dr. T has done that on a handful of patients,

Patient: Yes. So I just want to be patient. Doctor: Okay, and it may, and it very well may, because it’s just, uh, let’s see, it was done, you had the operation on-. Patient: Uh, on the fourteenth of September. Doctor: September? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So you’re not quite a year? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So alright well let’s, let’s continue with the same course. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And see what happens, alright? Patient: Um hum. I’ve been working and so, so you know, I’ve been keeping busy without that. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Alright. Very good.

Patient: Oh sure Doctor: But, if you don’t have any nausea, we have done everything that we needed to do and you feel great, you’ve got company to talk about – Hey, that wasn’t so bad. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: But, yeah, uh, you’ve gotta have a partner on those days. Patient: That’s fine. Just wanted to Doctor: There is no need to stay. She could leave for a couple of hours and come back. (chuckles) Family Member: Mmmmm. Doctor: Umm, but. Patient: How long then is, I know the infusion is like half an hour or something? Healthcare Professional: It’s an hour. Patient: It’s an hour. Okay. Then, how long before I get released? Doctor: Uh, the first time, they watch it for a half hour or so just to make sure you don’t have an allergic reaction.

Family Member: But I was on a higher dose. You’re saying, uh, a lower dose. Doctor: Yeah. What dose were you on? Family Member: Uh, well, when I, I was diagnosed with Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: They had put me on like, it was like eighty milligrams, but then they brought me down because my face was all ballooned out. Doctor: And so this is five a day, five milligrams. Family Member: Yes. It’s a small dose. Doctor: It’s a small, it’s relatively, it’s enough that, you know, it’s going to probably, well, depends. Some people don’t, some people actually even a little dose, they feel, some people feel like really good on it. They feel like they have more energy. Patient: Right. Doctor: Some people just feel weird. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it’s enough, a small enough dose, that you probably won’t notice it, but.

Family Member: Actually when you came out it was two point two. And then a week later we went to see his uh - Patient: General practitioner and - Family Member: So what is the reading today? Doctor: One point zero. Family Member: Wow! Doctor: So that is what it’s supposed to be. A new one. (background noise persists in addition to keyboarding sounds) Patient: Tomorrow I’m going to this local one. I have a schedule with Dr. ___in January because the last neurologist that I saw, the one that put the catheter in, told me the catheter should not be taken out in less than four to six weeks. It should be replaced in every four to six weeks if necessary. Doctor: Sure. Patient: So when I talked to ___, he said okay, then come in January and then we’ll that procedure. So I don’t know if I should go there. I don’t even know what else he can do. I didn’t have chance to talk to him personally. I talked to nurse and she did not explain correctly. Looks like he can’t do anything for me except the nurse is taking catheter out and putting it in. So what other treatments he’s going to give me, I don’t know. Doctor: Dr. ____ or Patient: Dr. ____. Doctor: And the issue really is we’d like to get the catheter out and sort of when is your bladder strong enough to take it out, if we’ve shrunk the cancer with the hormone therapy –

Patient: And that’s the um I guess that’s what’s (pause3secs) Healthcare Professional: Right, you just want to do what you have to, yes, exactly. No, we get that. Patient: Because I know there are so many side effects. Healthcare Professional: Right. Patient: So if where where the - we’re looking is probably radiation and sort of like not a complete hormone but like some sort of and I’m probably going to get some sort of a modified sense of a hormonal thing. So I’ll still have some effects of it, but in that effect so that the radiation if we do that part when we target it on what we know where it’s landed, the hormonal will be sort of be keeping everything else at bay at this point. Healthcare Professional: Right. Patient: So we know still it’s invisible somewhere, so we can target what we can see. And we can still deal with you know what we can’t see. If that’s the combination of your thinking in terms of correct or that is a possibility? Doctor: I’m thinking that in terms of the sequence if you get the radiotherapy first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That does not close the door to getting hormone therapy down the line. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You start with the hormone therapy, the other option is going to disappear very quickly. And a radiation oncologist is not going to know what to target.
